Wait, I think that more precisely if a topological field has a nontrivial path component, then its fundamental groupoid is equivalent to a discrete category.

A thin groupoid is a fancy name for a category where there's at most one morphism from any object to any other object, and this morphism is invertible. So it's a category where any two objects either have no morphisms between them, or exactly one isomorphism. So it's equivalent to the discrete category on its set of isomorphism classes.

It follows from the dichotomy theorem that there are two cases: either FFF is contractible or FFF is weakly homotopy equivalent to the discrete space with one component for each point in FFF. Since a contractible space is homotopy equivalent to a discrete space, in either case FFF is weakly homotopy equivalent to a discrete space!
This means that topological fields are 'boring' from a homotopy theorist's point of view - but there are two different ways for them to be boring.

Here I think is one way to produce topological rings with nontrivial fundamental groups. Please let me know if you see any problems. It proceeds through the following steps.

  • The functor B:Mon→CatB: \mathsf{Mon} \to \mathsf{Cat}B:Mon→Cat, sending a monoid MMM to the obvious 1-object category BMBMBM, is product-preserving. Being product-preserving, it sends abelian group objects in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon (which are the same as monoid objects in (Ab,×)(\mathsf{Ab}, \times)(Ab,×), which are the same as abelian groups) to abelian group objects in Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat. So for example, A=B(Z/2)A = B(\mathbb{Z}/2)A=B(Z/2) is an abelian group object in Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat.

  • Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat is cartesian closed. Given an abelian group object AAA in a cartesian closed category, its internal endo-hom object [A,A][A, A][A,A] carries a ring object structure, with addition being defined "internally pointwise", and multiplication given by internal composition. (For A=B(Z/2)A = B(\mathbb{Z}/2)A=B(Z/2), the underlying category of [A,A][A, A][A,A] is a finite category; this will be needed later.)

  • The nerve functor N:Cat→SetΔopN: \mathsf{Cat} \to \mathsf{Set}^{\Delta^{op}}N:Cat→SetΔop and the geometric realization functor R:SetΔop→TopR: \mathsf{Set}^{\Delta^{op}} \to \mathsf{Top}R:SetΔop→Top are both product-preserving. Here we need to be a little bit careful: for now, Top\mathsf{Top}Top denotes a [[convenient category of topological spaces]], such as the category CGWH\mathrm{CGWH}CGWH of compactly generated weakly Hausdorff spaces. Let's put a pin through that; I'll come back to this technical point in the next bullet point. In any case, the functor RN:Cat→TopRN: \mathsf{Cat} \to \mathsf{Top}RN:Cat→Top, being product-preserving, takes ring objects in Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat to ring objects in Top\mathsf{Top}Top, hence CGWH\mathrm{CGWH}CGWH-rings under one choice of notion of "convenient space".

  • A CGWH\mathrm{CGWH}CGWH-ring might not be a topological ring since products X×kYX \times_k YX×k​Y in CGWH\mathrm{CGWH}CGWH do not always match products X×YX \times YX×Y in topological spaces. But under certain circumstances, they do match. For this, I'll point to Theorem A.6 in Hatcher's Algebraic Topology (p. 524 of https://pi.math.cornell.edu/~hatcher/AT/AT.pdf), where if XXX and YYY are CW-complexes with countably many cells, then the canonical continuous map X×kY→X×YX \times_k Y \to X \times YX×k​Y→X×Y is a homeomorphism. This applies in particular if X=YX = YX=Y is the geometric realization of the nerve of a finite category, such as [A,A][A, A][A,A] above.

  • We may now deduce that RN([A,A])RN([A, A])RN([A,A]), with notation as above, is a topological ring. I claim this has nontrivial fundamental group (it's connected, by the way). This is because A=[1,A]A = [1, A]A=[1,A] is a retract of [A,A][A, A][A,A] (since 111 is a retract of AAA). If π1(RN([A,A]))\pi_1(RN([A, A]))π1​(RN([A,A])) were trivial, then so would be its retract π1(RNA)=π1(RNB(Z/2))\pi_1(RN A) = \pi_1(RNB(\mathbb{Z}/2))π1​(RNA)=π1​(RNB(Z/2)). One doofus error I made in my head was not using [A,A][A, A][A,A] for the internal abelian group hom, but just the internal hom.

Forming the internal abelian group hom requires that the ambient cartesian closed category has equalizers. In other words, you'd want to internally form what in sets would be written as {f:A→A∣  f(a+b)=f(a)+f(b)}\{f: A \to A|\; f(a + b) = f(a) + f(b)\}{f:A→A∣f(a+b)=f(a)+f(b)}, involving an equation. The left side of the equation f(a+b)f(a + b)f(a+b) would correspond to a map

[+,A]:[A,A]→[A×A,A][+, A]: [A, A] \to [A \times A, A][+,A]:[A,A]→[A×A,A]

that internally sends f:A→Af: A \to Af:A→A to the map (a,b)↦f(a+b)(a, b) \mapsto f(a + b)(a,b)↦f(a+b). The right side of the equation f(a)+f(b)f(a) + f(b)f(a)+f(b) corresponds to a composite

where the first map internally sends f:A→Af: A \to Af:A→A to the map (a,b)↦(f(a),f(b))(a, b) \mapsto (f(a), f(b))(a,b)↦(f(a),f(b)), and the second augments that map like so: (a,b)↦(f(a),f(b))↦f(a)+f(b)(a, b) \mapsto (f(a), f(b)) \mapsto f(a) + f(b)(a,b)↦(f(a),f(b))↦f(a)+f(b). The equalizer of these two maps

[A,A]⇉[A×A,A][A, A] \rightrightarrows [A \times A, A][A,A]⇉[A×A,A]

is the internal object of abelian group homomorphisms A→AA \to AA→A. Let's call that equalizer Ab(A,A)\mathsf{Ab}(A, A)Ab(A,A).
